columns.text: In this problem, we will compare two different assets that have different lifespans using the concept of equivalent annual costs.

First, we need to solve for the variable cost of each machine. For **machine A**, it states that the variable costs are $35\%$ of the annual sales. We will then have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost for A}&=\$13,000,000 \times 0.35\\[15 pt]
&=\$4, 550,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for A is $\$4,550,000$

For **machine B**, the variable cost is $30\%$ of the annual sales. We will then have:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Variable cost for B}&=\$13,000,000 \times 0.30\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,900,000
\end{aligned}$$

The variable cost for B is $\$3,900,000$
The next value that we will solve is the depreciation. Since it states in the problem that we will use straight-line depreciation, we will simply divide the initial cost by the number of years.

For the depreciation of **machine A**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation of A}&=\dfrac{\$2,900,000}{6}\\[15 pt]
&=\$483,333.33
\end{aligned}$$

Machine A depreciates at $\$483,333.33$ per year

For the depreciation of **machine B**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation of B}&=\dfrac{\$5,800,000}{9}\\[15 pt]
&=\$644,444.44
\end{aligned}$$

Machine B depreciates at $\$644,444.44$ per year

Now that we have these values, we can now solve for the earnings before interest and tax (EBIT). We can do this by simply adding costs and the depreciation.

For **machine A**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT for A}&=\$4,550,000 +\$210,000+\$483,333.33\\[15 pt]
&=\$5,243,333.33
\end{aligned}$$

The EBIT for machine A is then $\$5,243,333.33$

For **machine B**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{EBIT for A}&=\$3,900,000+\$245,000+\$644,444.44\\[15 pt]
&=\$4,789,444.44
\end{aligned}$$

The EBIT for machine B is then $\$4,789,444.44$

Now for the earnings after tax, we will multiply the EBIT to one minus the tax rate.

For **Machine A**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings after tax}&=\$5,243,333.33\times(1-0.24)\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,984,933.33
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings after tax for A is $\$3,984,933.33$

For **Machine A**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Earnings after tax}&=\$4,789,444.44\times(1-0.24)\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,639,977.77
\end{aligned}$$

The earnings after tax for B is $\$3,639,977.77$

Next, we will get the operating cash flow. In order to do this, simply subtract the depreciation to the earnings after tax. 

For **Machine A**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow for A}&=\$3,984,933.33-\$483,333.33\\[15 pt]
&=\$3,501,600
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for A is $3,501,600$

For **Machine B**:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Operating cash flow for B}&=\$3,639,977.77-\$644,444.44\\[15 pt]
&=\$2,995,533.33
\end{aligned}$$

The operating cash flow for B is $2,995,533.33$

Solving for the net present value of **Machine A**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value of A}&=-\$2,900,000 -(\$3,501,600 \times 4.35526)\\[15 pt]
&=-\$18,150,378.42
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value for machine A is $-\$18,150,378.42$

Solving for the net present value of **Machine B**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value of B}&=-\$5,800,000-(\$2,995,533.33\times 5.75902)\\[15 pt]
&=-\$23,051,336.36
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value for machine B is $-\$23,051,336.36$
Now that we have the net present value and the annuity factor, we can solve for the equivalent annual cost for each machine then decide which is the better choice.

Substituting the values to the formula in Step 2, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equivalent annual cost for A}&=\dfrac{-\$18,150,378.42}{4.35526}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$4,167,461.51
\end{aligned}$$

The equivalent annual cost for **Machine A** is $-\$4,167,461.51$

Now, for **Machine B**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equivalent annual cost for B}&=\dfrac{-\$23,051,336.36}{5.75902}\\[15 pt]
&=-\$4,002,649.12
\end{aligned}$$

The equivalent annual cost for **Machine B** is $-\$4,002,649.12$

Based on the calculated values, **Machine B** has a more positive value which means that it operates at a lower annual cost compared to Machine A. Therefore, **Machine B** should be chosen by the firm.
